↳ In-reply-to ¬ª Why is Go so popular? I haven't understood the appeal of Go, and I seek to change my mind. (I mean the programming language, not the board game.)

@nmke-de@yarn.zn80.net I can only speak for myself in answering this. Go for me is the better Python. Go has the right balance of performance, ease of use and feature that I like in a language. Not too much (like C#, Java, etc) and not too little like C

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @markwylde No, it doesn't have to be this way, but it is (almost) always this way. When a programming language makes it too easy to manage dependencies, you inevitably get microdependencies. It doesn't help that many people learn JavaScript or Python as their first language.

@mckinley Thankfully less so in Go, because of the culture around the language, but I used to feel this way about Python too once upon a time, I feel like languages and ecosystems get ‚Äúpopulated‚Äù with ideas from every other language/ecosystem over time and eventually reach a state of ‚Äúchaos‚Äù? ü§î As an example, Go now supports generics as of Go 1.19, something I‚Äôm not really all that thrilled with really as it adds unnecessary complexity to the language IMO that isn‚Äôt really needed.

↳ In-reply-to ¬ª @markwylde No, it doesn't have to be this way, but it is (almost) always this way. When a programming language makes it too easy to manage dependencies, you inevitably get microdependencies. It doesn't help that many people learn JavaScript or Python as their first language.

@mckinley Is right here, as much as I‚Äôm strongly opinionated on the subject, there is no ‚Äúhard‚Äù and ‚Äúfast‚Äù (right or wrong) rule here. There are only ‚Äúrules of thumb‚Äù, ‚Äúguidelines‚Äù and ‚Äúexperience‚Äù.

And as @mckinley nicely points out, the real problem is likely the exponential effect of dependencies. Fortunately or unfortunately (depending on how you look at it) libraries can also have dependencies (and good language really will support this), but the thing we often refer to as ‚Äúdependency hell‚Äù comes from this ‚Äúexponential dependency tree‚Äù that we inevitably see in ecosystems like NodeJS / NPM (are there other examples? I feel like I pick on NodeJS / NPM too much ü§£)
